pr_title: Add shift and range expression parsing

timeline.message: Add shift and range expressions support
Fix falling test cases with new feature
Fix parser crashing with type-cast-expr recovery
Modify syntax tree descriptor for <<, >>, >>> nodes and generate tree
Add <<, >>, >>> operator support at parser level and modify test cases accordingly

timeline.bodyText:
In here we have to check whether next tokens belong to a type-cast-expr. It seems it is not possible unless we process up to the >. i.e. next token being an @ or isTypeStartingToken does not always imply a type-cast-expr start.
Even if we processed up to >, still there's ambiguity.
e.g.  a <<b> c  could mean either a << (b > c) or a < (<b> c)
So feel like it is better not  allow a <<int> b; to be parsed as a type-cast-expr.
Only  a < <int> b; is allowed. That way we don't need nodes for <<, >>, >>> at parser level. WDT?
timeline.author: lochana-chathura

replies.bodyText:
According to the spec, type-cast has higher-precedence over shift/compare expressions. So a <<b> c is correct to be parsed as a <(<b> c). If the user wants the other behaviour, he can use parenthesis.
But yea, like you've said, we have to go and parse the component after < to determine the operator. Let me have a look and get back.
